channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Battle Between 2 State Giants, CCTV and Bank of China, Unravels
item.description: The state broadcaster CCTV, itself mired in corruption scandals, has accused one of the country’s biggest banks of money laundering in a report that provoked both surprise and cynicism.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A Bank of China branch in Beijing. The state lender is the eighth largest in the world in terms of assets.

item.title: More Than Half the Global Population Is Urban, Report Finds
item.description: The report, by the United Nations, said India’s pace of urbanization has surpassed that of China, the previous leader.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Barcelona Journal: Marijuana Clubs Rise Out of Decades-Old Spanish Laws
item.description: Barcelona’s cannabis clubs have some experts saying the city will soon challenge Amsterdam as the go-to destination for vacationers who want to get high in peace.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Enric Juncosa, who uses marijuana as therapy for his sclerosis, at a cannabis club in Barcelona.

item.title: In Beijing, Kerry Focuses on Areas of Agreement
item.description: The secretary of state sought to highlight commonalities between China and the United States after the Chinese dismissed assertions that hackers had infiltrated federal computer systems.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: Candidates Raise Specter of Cheating in Indonesia Presidential Vote
item.description: Though quick counts project Joko Widodo as the winner, his opponent, Prabowo Subianto, accused him of trying to hijack the country’s democracy.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Gaza Deaths Spike in Third Day of Israel Air Assaults
item.description: At least 78 Palestinians were said to have died as of Thursday, while rocket attacks from Gaza reached new areas in Israel.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The mother of Hamed Shehab, 27, who officials said was killed in an Israeli airstrike on a car used by a local news agency, during his funeral on Thursday in Gaza City.

item.title: Missile Kills 8 at Beachside Gaza Cafe
item.description: The cafe, where patrons were about to watch the World Cup, was hit by a missile apparently targeting what Israel’s military later described as a single terrorist.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: Myanmar Court Sentences Journalists to 10 Years of Hard Labor in Prison
item.description: Burmese journalists said the jail terms in connection with an article about possible chemical weapons production were a blow to recently won freedoms.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: France Is Not an Anti-Semitic Nation
item.description: The number of hateful acts against Jews has fallen over the last decade. Fighting prejudice remains our moral duty.
item.dc:creator: By LAURENT FABIUS and BERNARD CAZENEUVE

item.title: Germany Demands Top U.S. Intelligence Officer Be Expelled
item.description: The move came because Washington has refused to cooperate with German inquiries into United States intelligence officials, Berlin says.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Clemens Binninger, chairman of the German parliamentary committee controlling intelligence services, addressed the spying scandal in Berlin on Thursday.

item.title: South Africa Delays Ruling on Parole for Apartheid-Era Killer
item.description: The case of Eugene de Kock, a convicted death-squad leader known as “Prime Evil,” reflects South Africa’s long struggle to come to terms with its brutal past.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Kurdish Leader Calls for Iraqi Premier to Resign
item.description: Following criticism from the prime minister, the Kurdish regional government said its ministers would boycott cabinet meetings and demanded an apology.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Massoud Barzani, president of the Kurdish regional government, arriving for a parliamentary session in the regional capital of Erbil this month.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Police Detain Party Critic for Role in Tiananmen Commemoration
item.description: Murong Xuecun, a prominent critic of the Communist Party whose real name is Hao Qun, was detained by the police in Beijing for his role in a small commemoration of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and MIA LI
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Journalists Warned Not to Work With Foreign Media
item.description: The Chinese government has issued a new directive that alerts local journalists not to pass on any information obtained in the course of their work to any foreign media groups or to domestic media where they are not employed.
item.dc:creator: By KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: Journalists working at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing. A new directive requires Chinese journalists to sign nondisclosure agreements, pledging not to transmit state secrets.

item.title: Letter From Europe: British Combatants of a Different Religious War
item.description: Since the so-called Arab Spring, a new militancy has arisen, beckoning Muslims in Britain and other parts of the West to join the ranks of the holy warriors.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Philip Toscano/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The memorial to the victims of the London terrorist attacks of July 7, 2005.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Sarkozy’s Reckless Political Encore
item.description: To fend off corruption charges, he is borrowing from the populist right’s playbook.
item.dc:creator: By ARTHUR GOLDHAMMER

item.title: ‘Low-Grade’ Nuclear Material Is Seized by Rebels in Iraq, U.N. Says
item.description: The International Atomic Energy Agency says the material, taken by Sunni insurgents, does not present a significant security threat.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Latin America’s Talent for Tolerance
item.description: Today, violent and fanatic racism is the exception and not the rule in our part of the world.
item.dc:creator: By ENRIQUE KRAUZE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Li Chengpeng’s Social Media and Blog Accounts Suspended
item.description: The commentator’s Sina Weibo and Tencent Weibo microblog and blog accounts disappeared Monday evening in what appears to be part of China’s continuing effort to muzzle outspoken voices online.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN

item.title: Brazilians Grumble and Take Stock After Crushing World Cup Loss
item.description: While the hope was to blot out the bad memory of the last time the country hosted the World Cup, the outcome was if anything worse. But in a more mature Brazil, people are asking whether it will matter as much.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: U.S. Counterterrorism Chief to Step Down
item.description: Matthew G. Olsen has been director of the National Counterterrorism Center as threats from Al Qaeda shifted from Pakistan to Syria, Iraq and Yemen.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: New-Design Rocket Is Launched
item.description: Russia launched the Angara rocket, its first new design of space rocket since the Soviet era, from the northern military space port of Plesetsk.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Counterterrorism Chief Stepping Down
item.description: Matthew G. Olsen, the director of the National Counterterrorism Center, is resigning after three years.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: World Briefing: Switzerland: Former Banker Is Charged
item.description: A Swiss prosecutor brought charges on Wednesday against Rudolf Elmer, a former banker in the Cayman Islands with the Swiss bank Julius Baer.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Egypt Silent as Neighbors Wage Battles
item.description: Egyptians appear to be barely lifting a finger as the Gaza death toll mounts, leaving the Palestinians and the Israelis without a go-between.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
